pageContext.claim: “Democrat UAW Local 1112 President David Green ought to get his act together and produce. G.M. let our Country down, but other much better car companies are coming into the U.S. in droves. I want action on Lordstown fast. Stop complaining and get the job done! 3.8% Unemployment!”
pageContext.analysis: Trump attacked a union leader for General Motors's decision to close the auto plant in Lordstown, Ohio, after Green appeared on Fox News. The annoucement was made in November and production had ended on March 6, with GM saying it was making the cuts, in the words of the chief executive, to “to get in front of it while the company is strong and while the economy is strong." Green, the union leader, had written Trump four months before the announcement urging him to get involved to save the plant. He noted the company would save billions from the Trump tax cut and he urged that the president press the company to reinvest the tax savings in Lordstown. He says he did not hear back from Trump. Green participated in the negotiations when the Lordstown plant workers agreed in 2007 to pay new hires lower wages — about $20 an hour instead of $30. During the 2016 presidential campaign, Trump had told auto workers their jobs were safe and more would be coming if he became president. "They're all coming back. They're all coming back," Trump assured supporters in a rally in nearby Youngstown. "Don't move. Don't sell your house."
